title: 108_hr4975
content: The "Pay Back America Act of 2004" imposes a $3 per passenger tax on covered international voyages, to be paid by the provider of the voyage either at embarkation or disembarkation in the United States. "Definition section under SEC. 4476 of the Pay Back America Act of 2004." The term 'covered international voyage' refers to a commercial passenger vessel voyage that includes overnight stays, with passengers embarking or disembarking in the United States and outside the country. It excludes voyages on vessels owned or operated by the US, a State, or its agencies. A 'passenger vessel' is defined as a vessel with accommodations for more than 16 passengers. A conforming amendment is made to Section 6806 of the Code. The amendments made by this section apply to passengers embarking or disembarking in the United States after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 3. ESTABLISHMENT OF TRUST FUNDS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to establish the CARIBBEAN PORTS AND INFRASTRUCTURE PROTECTION TRUST FUND. The Caribbean Ports and Infrastructure Protection Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on international water transportation. Payments are made from the fund to countries like the Bahamas, Cayman Islands, Barbados, Jamaica, Saint Lucia, and Grenada. Section 9602(b) is related to the amount described in subparagraph (A). SEC. 9512 establishes the Water and Marine Wildlife Protection Trust Fund. The Water and Marine Wildlife Protection Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on international water transportation. The fund is used for environmental programs to clean up waste in the oceans and enforce restrictions on waste dumping. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 98 of the Code. SEC. 4. REQUIREMENTS RELATING TO PREVENTION OF POLLUTION FROM VESSELS. This section outlines regulations aimed at preventing pollution from vessels. The Congress finds that pollution prevention devices on vessels are crucial for reducing pollution, and biannual inspections of these devices will ensure they are fully operational. Additionally, fabricated entries in vessel oil record books have been found to give a false sense of compliance with pollution discharge limitations. The Act aims to deter unlawful discharges at sea by recording shore-side disposal of garbage and sludge, making violations a felony with stiff fines. Cruise vessels entering US ports must display a notice for reporting illegal dumping. The Act aims to deter unlawful discharges at sea by making violations a felony with stiff fines. Cruise vessels entering US ports must display a notice for reporting illegal dumping to the Coast Guard. To prevent violations, vessels must have proper functioning prevention equipment and comply with regulations. It is illegal to make false entries in oil record books or records of garbage disposal. Cruise vessels must comply with regulations when operating in US commerce and tickets must include required notices. The Secretary of the department shall inspect vessels biannually to ensure they have required pollution prevention equipment, it functions properly, and cruise vessels comply with regulations. Violators will face fines or imprisonment. This section aims to prevent violations related to pollution prevention equipment on vessels. The section aims to ensure cruise vessels comply with pollution prevention regulations. A cruise vessel is defined as a passenger vessel authorized to carry at least 250 passengers with onboard sleeping facilities. It excludes vessels operated by the US or state governments. The term "passenger" on a cruise vessel includes any person on board for travel, whether a paying passenger or staff member like a crew member or officer.
